title: Problem Overview
content: Erdős #1008 asks whether every graph with m edges has a C₄-free subgraph with ≫ m^{2/3} edges. Originally posed with exponent 3/4 (disproved by Folkman), the 2/3 version was proved by Conlon-Fox-Sudakov in 2014. The exponent is optimal.

title: 4-Cycles and C₄-Freeness
content: A C₄ (4-cycle) is a cycle a-b-c-d-a on 4 distinct vertices. We define hasC4 to detect such cycles and isC4Free as their absence. Note that C₄ = K_{2,2}, connecting this to the Zarankiewicz problem.

title: Subgraphs and Edge Count
content: A subgraph H of G uses only edges from G. The edge count is simply the cardinality of the edge set. The problem asks: how many edges can we keep while eliminating all 4-cycles?

title: Trivial Bound: m^{1/2}
content: Erdős noted that m^{1/2} is trivially achievable. By Kővári–Sós–Turán, C₄-free graphs on n vertices have O(n^{3/2}) edges. Greedily removing edges from 4-cycles gives a C₄-free subgraph with Ω(√m) edges.

title: Folkman's Counterexample
content: Folkman disproved the m^{3/4} conjecture using K_{n,n²}. This graph has n³ edges, but every C₄-free subgraph has only O(n²) = O((n³)^{2/3}) edges. This shows 3/4 is impossible and 2/3 is the best we can hope for.

title: Main Result: m^{2/3}
content: Conlon, Fox, and Sudakov (2014) proved the optimal bound: every graph with m edges has a C₄-free subgraph with Ω(m^{2/3}) edges. The exponent 2/3 matches Folkman's lower bound, so this is tight.

title: Generalization to K_{s,t}
content: The problem generalizes: K_{2,2} = C₄ is just one case. The Conlon-Fox-Sudakov paper proves results for avoiding K_{s,t} for general s,t. This connects to the classical Zarankiewicz problem in extremal graph theory.
